did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.abstract: The John L. Heatwole Collection, 1802-1901, consists of three folders containing 102 items pertaining to Shenandoah Valley history. The collection is arranged into three series: General Valley Documents, Page County Documents, and Recipes.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Donated to Carrier Library by John L. Heatwole of Bridgewater, VA on several occasions beginning in December 1987.

bioghist.head: Biographical Information
bioghist.p: Born March 24, 1948, John L. Heatwole was an artist, woodcarver, and local historian and folklorist. After serving in the U.S. Marine Corps and working at the Library of Congress, Heatwole moved to Dayton with his wife, Miriam. Throughout his lifetime he sat on various committees and boards related to both art and history, and received several awards for his work. He also authored several books relating to superstitions, folkways, and the Civil War. Heatwole was dedicated to preserving Shenandoah Valley history and folklore as is reflected in this collection of materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The John L. Heatwole Collection, 1802-1901, consists of three folders containing 102 items pertaining to Shenandoah Valley history. The collection is arranged into three series: General Valley Documents, Page County Documents, and Recipes.

Series One, General Valley Documents, includes arrest warrants, summons, orders for seizure of goods for non-payment of debt, legal reciepts, tax receipts, and business letterheads. Individual items are chronologically arranged and described to the item level as per the donor's explanatory notes. Documents related to the Zigler Family of Tomberville have been placed at the front of the folder and consist of five receipts for muster fines and orders granting private entertainment to John or David Zigler, 1828-1850.
Series Two, Page County Documents, contains various court documents, summons, treasury receipts, handwritten receipts, and orders for the seizure of goods for non-payment of debt.

Series Three, Recipes, consists of two handwritten and two printed recipes for herbal cures and a recipe for making gunpowder. One recipe, printed in Pennsylvania Dutch or a variation of German, gives steps for curing a "mad dog bite" (i.e. rabies). A second recipe, also written in Pennsylvania Dutch, describes an incantation against sties. For complete translations see John L. Heatwole's Shenandoah Voices: Folklore, Legends and Traditions of the Valley (Berryville, VA: Rockbridge Publishing Company, 1995), 47, 57-59.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in three series.
